description:
Bradyrhizobium erythrophlei is a species of nitrogen-fixing bacteria that forms symbiotic relationships with the roots of certain leguminous plants, specifically the tree species Erythrophleum fordii, also known as the Ironwood tree.

This bacterium is a slow-growing, aerobic, Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that belongs to the genus Bradyrhizobium. It is capable of fixing atmospheric nitrogen through the process of biological nitrogen fixation, which occurs within specialized root nodules formed on the host plant.

The symbiotic relationship between Bradyrhizobium erythrophlei and Erythrophleum fordii is beneficial to both organisms. The bacteria provide the plant with fixed nitrogen, which the plant can then use for growth and development, while the plant provides the bacteria with carbohydrates and other nutrients necessary for their survival.

This species of Bradyrhizobium is found primarily in the soil environments where Erythrophleum fordii trees are naturally found, typically in tropical and subtropical regions. It plays an important role in the nutrient cycling and ecosystem functioning of these forest habitats.
